title: The Update That Never Shipped
description: A firmware staging server has been hijacked, threatening to deploy malicious updates.

scenes.narrative: You've accessed the server room where the firmware staging occurs. Network logs show unusual traffic patterns, but the server appears normal.

choices.label: Talk to the server administrator to understand the update process.
choices.consequence: The admin reveals the hijacking method used to access the staging area.

choices.label: Analyze network traffic for injection points.
choices.consequence: You identify the exact moment and method of the server compromise.

choices.label: Deploy network monitoring tools to trace the intrusion.
choices.consequence: Tools capture the attacker's command sequence and IP trail.

choices.label: The server room feels staged - check for physical tampering.
choices.consequence: You find physical access ports that were used to bypass network security.

scenes.narrative: The malicious firmware update is set to deploy in minutes. You need to stop it while preserving evidence.

choices.label: Coordinate with IT team to isolate the server safely.
choices.consequence: The team helps contain the breach without triggering the update.

choices.label: Calculate the deployment window and intervene precisely.
choices.consequence: You stop the update with seconds to spare, preserving all evidence.

choices.label: Use emergency override tools to halt the deployment.
choices.consequence: Override tools successfully prevent the malicious update from shipping.

choices.label: This deployment timing is too perfect - it's a test run.
choices.consequence: You discover the update was a probe, not the real attack, saving resources.
